column4: ssh user@work.example.org -L 10000:172.16.10.10:22 -g keeps me just listening in 127.0.0.1 and not globally like it should
any hints on this?
!blacklist
try ssh user@work.example.org -L *:10000:172.16.10.22
:22 at the end
take a look at /var/log/syslog after the login attempt, it may point at a permissions issue with the .authorized_keys file.
will look into that right now
I just have pam session messages, no authorized_keys concerned lines
just to cover the basics, you created the .ssh/authorized_keys file is on the server and it has your id_pub key in it?
can you try ssh -v servername pastebin that :)
http://pastebin.com/7KcqQzX5
can you also give a pastbin of tail -100 /var/log/auth.log
http://pastebin.com/AydezCB8
one last one pastebin of ls -la ~/.ssh on the server
http://pastebin.com/mMRQJwPz
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/authorized_keys
http://pastebin.com/A87F5Umb
does this return anything: cd ~/.ssh l grep `cat id_rsa.pub | cut -f2 -d" "` authorized_keys
sorry that should be : cd ~/.ssh ; grep `cat id_rsa.pub | cut -f2 -d" "` authorized_keys
blank, nothing
in ~/.ssh run cat id_rsa.pub >> authorized_keys
OMFG, you ARE a genius! , thank you
sorry should have checked the basics first :) that command added your public key to the authorized file.
Ben64: thank you very much guys, good bye
